Title: We are all Ayotzinapa: The role of Digital Media in the Shaping of Transnational Memories on Disappearance

This project investigates the critical role of digital media in shaping transnational memories of disappearance, with a focus on the 2014 disappearance of 43 students in Mexico. The significance of this research lies in its potential to illuminate the impact of new media on citizen engagement and the counter-movement against the Mexican government. By adopting a multidisciplinary approach, combining theoretical and comparative analyses, this study will provide a nuanced understanding of disappearance as a crime and its representation in digital memory.

The project will comparatively examine Mexico's case alongside social performances and artistic representations in Spain and Argentina, highlighting the long transnational history of disappearance in the Hispanic World. Through this research, we aim to develop a theoretical model for analyzing digital mnemonic objects and networked social movements with transnational scope. This model will enable scholars and practitioners to better understand the ontological status of the disappeared and the boundaries transgressed in digital memory.

The proposed project's output will be a groundbreaking theoretical framework that sheds light on the complex interplay between digital media, memory, and social movements. By exploring the ways in which digital media shapes our understanding of disappearance, this research will contribute to a deeper comprehension of the power dynamics at play in the construction of transnational memories. Ultimately, this project seeks to inspire new forms of citizen engagement and advocacy, promoting accountability and justice for the victims of disappearance and their families.
